text: thanks so much for the introduction and
also of course to everyone who made this
possible and to all the speakers from
the amazing sessions that we've heard in
the morning so the story that I'd like
to tell you about today is about
methodology development fundamentally
and it's the story of going to bigger
magnets faster magicangle spinning and a
stronger detection nucleus in this case
protons but first I'll tell you a little
bit about myself and my geographic
trajectory I started off in Boulder
Colorado and I basically went east and
north that's much more random than it
appears I grew up at the foothills of
the Rockies and mountains like these and
I enjoyed a lot of outdoor activities
skiing hiking fishing you name it and I
had an interest in early on and in
building things and making things that
seem like a exciting way to contribute
and that's me on the right there with
partly unfinished viola that I made in
those days so I figured that with my
interest in building things I should
become an engineer or mechanical
engineer I thought and I was all set to
go to engineering school in Colorado but
then at the last moment I was bumped off
the wait list at Oberlin College and I
changed plans and decided that a liberal
arts college would be a more interesting
place to be at an intersection that
would allow me to be around much more
music and at Oberlin I started to take
chemistry courses only because I really
had to for the engineering but I got
more and more interested in and at
really enjoying these courses and I did
undergraduate research with Manish Mayta
this is my first publication with him
where we became interested in the
problem of protein folding as you
probably know the fold of complicated
biological molecules is not easy to
predict and so there's a large effort by
a variety of experimental techniques to
determine those structures and this is
the well known protein folding problem
in this case we started off with what
you might choke English Ollie mono
protein in this case the structure of a
single amino acid histidine but this is
about the method development
we started here and then continued from
there I went on to do a PhD with Bob
Griffin at MIT and I learned a lot in
Bob's lab a lot more about NMR there and
I'd like to repeat one of the things
that Bob likes to say and that is that
there are really three important things
in NMR and those three things are first
sensitivity the second thing is
sensitivity and you probably guessed
that the third thing is still
sensitivity this is really true that if
we only had more sensitivity we could do
many many things we could go to higher
dimensional spectra we can trade some
resolution we can resolution enhanced by
trading some sensitivity and in Bob's
lab our method of enhancing the signals
was something called dynamic nuclear
polarization basically this amounts to
using the stronger polarization from
electrons transferring them to nuclei
and then detecting and with this we can
achieve orders of magnitude signal
enhancement but to do this we needed a
lot of specialized equipment which and
that lab was often home built here you
see a much tidier image of that
equipment with a gyrotron oscillator
microwave waveguide sampled temperatures
of around 100 Kelvin cryoprotectants
doping the sample with radicals and to
do this we could determine interesting
determine interesting biological
features of molecules in this case a
membrane protein really the important
part has just introduced is that with
this kind of technology we can study
these proteins in a very near native
context I haven't actually done work in
whole cells but in this case what I mean
by near-native is for a membrane protein
in a lipid bilayer environment and
sometimes this in it turns out to be
extremely important to be sure that
we're studying the structure of the
molecule in its native environment in
its native structure
after my PhD I moved to Europe I went to
France to work in the group of cuido
Penta CUDA at the high field NMR Center
in lyon also under the scientific
direction of linden Emsley and here the
focus was on a different method for
sensitivity enhancement which you might
call a brute-force method in some ways
going to the strongest magnetic fields
we possibly can
spinning faster and detecting protons on
this slide you can see we could now
reach considerably larger molecules and
what we did here was to determine the
structure of the dynamic the basic
dimeric unit inside intact nucleo capsid
of 2 point 5 mega Dalton's and size
something that we were we're quite proud
to see that we could do with this
technology so here I'd like to explain a
little bit what we do in in magicangle
spinning an NMR in general we orient our
sample at a particular angle and spin
and this transforms a very broad
spectrum that we would have in a static
sample to a narrow spectrum that you'll
you are all probably familiar with what
we like to call solution like spectra on
the right and this shows here a carbon
spectrum so what we'd like to do is be
able to apply this same technology but
detect protons because protons have a
four times larger gyromagnetic ratio
meaning a four times larger magnetic
moment for detection but to do this we
need to spin much faster and the bottom
here you can see the progression of
rotor sizes over the years getting
smaller and smaller which allows us to
spin faster and faster and these last
two here are what really this is the
technological breakthrough that really
allows us to make an advancement and to
detect protons to protons detected
spectroscopy more generally and all of
this we need to do at the highest
magnetic fields that are possible which
until recently was 1 gigahertz
this shows visually the improvement that
we can reach when we spin faster going
from 40 kilohertz up to 111 kilohertz
magicangle spinning just for a model
protein
in addition we can get the sample
required down to half a milligram this
is very important for many of the
membrane proteins that we're interested
in since they can only be expressed in
limited quantities now the magnetic
field as I mentioned already also plays
an important role not just in the
sensitivity but also in the resolution
and this slide shows the progression
from 500 megahertz to 1 gigahertz and
we're very excited to see what will be
possible with 1.2 gigahertz spectroscopy
which has just been announced at the NMR
conferences which actually coincide
exactly with this one that the
instrument manufacturer has now brought
to field in-home homogenized a magnet at
1.2 gigahertz so we're excited to be
able to use this soon just one slide
with a lot of numbers to quantify the
improvement a lot of these numbers are a
bit different from sample to sample but
if we add up many different small
improvements we can really have a big
step change in the sensitivity allowing
us to apply this spectroscopy more
broadly so we get modest improvements
with magnetic field a large improvement
with move to protons then we need
smaller rotors this results in some
signal loss but it's made up for by
having a detection coil which is very
tightly around the sample has a stronger
inductive coupling to the sample we can
often recycle the experiment repeating
the experiment faster this gives us some
additional improvement and finally we
have longer coherence lifetimes this
means that our signal survives through
our complicated pull sequences and
reaches the end for detection and if we
add this all together we can come up
with numbers of approximately four to
ten an improvement in sensitivity which
may not sound like much but considering
the time needed goes as the square this
really leads to orders of magnitude
improvement in an experiment time that
we need for these these studies so in a
nutshell taking a real example we just
calculated this recently during my PhD
days we had
used mainly carbon detected methods for
structure determination of this membrane
protein it took seven different
isotopically labeled samples months of
data and we could only do
two-dimensional spectroscopy for
sensitivity reasons and now with proton
detection we can get this down to just
one sample a couple of weeks and now we
can apply three-dimensional spectroscopy
which is important to reduce the amount
of redundancy that we have fundamentally
in the data and this is the focus now of
my group in gutting and I know for the
last three years been leading the solid
state NMR team in gutting in in the MPI
for biophysical chemistry and this shows
the five different membrane proteins
that we are focusing on with a variety
of different functions which I won't
have time to go into detail here but
just want to make the point one more
time that the context of the protein can
really matter and recently we studied a
protein where this is very obvious this
is eight stranded beta-barrel membrane
protein and on the left you see the
structure and lipids on there on the
right the structure that we calculated
in detergents
now many biophysical characterization
methods for structural biology make use
of these detergents or similar
detergents in this case it's October ko
side which is considered to be a very
mild detergent but in this case the
detergent leads to complete loss of
structure at the top of the molecule
outside the membrane and this of course
leads to a very different conclusion
about the possible function of this
molecule since we use the structure as
an indication for a starting point to
understand the function in these
proteins
so with that I'd like to summarize we
don't do very many reactions it's more
in analytical lab but this is a reaction
that we really like we always start off
with a sample we then apply we pack this
sample into very small rotors apply the
fastest spinning we can at the highest
magnetic fields we can and the result of
this is a high-resolution spectrum then
in a second step we apply students
postdocs and we found that free coffee
in the department really accelerates
this reaction and we can calculate then
structures in a native environment like
the one you see at the right there are
many people to think and the too many to
name on one slide so I just put the
pictures up for the main mentors that
I've had over the years and I've also
shown at the bottom here the solid state
and Ammar group that I've been leading
for the last three years who I now rely
on for many many things and what you've
seen today and of course none of this
would be possible without the many
funding agencies Thanks
[Applause]
